question 1: Who the fuck is Paul Watson

I'll give you the skinny chief since not everyone will google him.  4 year player undrafted out of Fresno State. Average G league player for 2 years on Westchester Knicks. Raps 905 head coach Jama Mahlalela went to some sort of g league elite type event that Paul also attended and raved about Paul to the front office.  Fall 2019 Raps 905 traded some guy and a G league draft pick to the Westchester Knicks for Paul Watson Jr. Things seemed to come together for Watson, on the Raps 905 as he massively improved his shooting on higher usage. He Signed a two year 2 way contract January 2020, had one notable 22 pts game vs Denver in the bubble.   Watson earned an NBA contract in training camp coming into this season. He mostly played garbage minutes and was deep in the rotation and didn't look great. After some trades he got more playing time and was looking okay before he got covid and missed about 3 weeks. This was his 2nd game coming back.

yea, this isn't comparable to sterling.   and there's plenty in the article IMO that just feels like "ok this is racist how?"  especially with how he wanted to fire watson after an argument with Rich paul unless Watson left the klutch group.

Also Watson pointed out Rich Paul isn't his agent. His agency is Klutch but he has a different agent. Maybe Paul did offend Sarver but it's pretty unprofessional to try and force someone to cut ties for that.
Lol no it flat out wasn‚Äôt the issue. Sarver was pissed Rich Paul took a shot at him and wanted Watson to leave his agency.

I totally agree with you here. The writer is grasping at straws a few times. I also think this inclusion is sorta stupid  >Watson said he explained to Sarver the optics of a white owner asking a Black coach to fire an agency led by a Black agent, Paul.  Sarver was insulted by Paul and had already wanted Paul and Watson to break up due to conflict of interest, which makes sense.  Seems like race should be irrelevant here and they just brought it up to gaslight him

> Through legal representation, Sarver said his issue with Klutch was solely due to a conflict of interest -- that a coach and a player could not be represented by the same agent. Sarver denied that the conversation had anything to do with race. Watson, when told of Sarver's response, said: "Rich [Paul] was never my agent." Watson was represented by Klutch Sports, which is owned by Paul.  > "Guess who did my contract when I got hired to be a head coach [with the Suns]? Klutch," Watson said. "If Klutch did my contract, wouldn't [the Suns] have just told me, 'We can't sign you because it's a conflict of interest?' They did my interim contract, and they did my other contract. They did two contracts for me."  Jfc Sarver can't even get his stories straight. Also, I seriously better not see a single scumbag in this thread bitching about cancel culture. This shit is abhorrent, so keep your dumbass thoughts to yourself.
I don't think Paul Watson is the guy to push us over the top this year.

I‚Äôm not sure fully but in addition to that, Sarver apparently told Watson he needed to fire Rich Paul because of the Eric Bledsoe extension or something with that and Watson said no because Klutch was his agency when he signed on initially as an interim then when he got promoted to head coach klutch did the paperwork. So he refused to fire klutch, so apparently Sarver fired him for that as well

If you read the story, Watson kind of suggested to Sarver he would make it a race thing if Sarver wanted him to get rid of Rich Paul. He also says what Sarvers problem is with Rich Paul, and it has nothing to do with race at all. Like, not even close.     James Jones is also quoted as saying Watson was toxic and saying shit that didn't represent the suns value on more than one occasion.      Like Watson certainly sounds like he has an axe to grind and had threatened him with this.

"Blatant racism"  isn't slamming papers on a desk dude.      The allegations of him saying the N word are coming from Earl Watson, who they fired for being toxic. Who is quoted in this article as having suggested to Sarver that he would make it a race issue if he wanted him to get rid of Rich Paul. It wasn't a race issue, considering they also said he was mad at Rich Paul for telling him he didn't know anything about basketball. He was just pissed Rich Paul insulted him. Nothing to do with race.      I'm not speaking on what is or isn't offensive, but this report isn't nearly the bombshell it was made out to be.

I'm confused how firing Watson would hurt either Watson or Paul, aren't coaches contracts fully guanteed the moment it is signed? The only thing I can think of is if Sarver knew Watson wouldn't get another job in the NBA again, but if you have a coach no one else wants do you even want that coach?

A lot of the allegations of explicitly racist stuff that weren't him being out of touch and quoting someone saying the n-word like 15 years ago seem to be sourced from Earl Watson, but a lot of the Watson anecdotes seem to not make very much sense to me.   >"I don't like diversity," Sarver replied, according to Watson and a basketball operations staffer with knowledge of the interaction.  Racist or not, this just seems unlikely to me given the other quotes in the article and Sarver's philanthropic projects.  >"Yeah, I will f---ing fire you," Sarver told Watson. "You have 10 days to think about it. Don't wait too long."  >Watson said he explained to Sarver the optics of a white owner asking a Black coach to fire an agency led by a Black agent, Paul.  >"Yeah, I understand what race you two are," Sarver replied, according to Watson. "So I'm asking you, How bad do you want your job?"  The whole article was really bad, especially the misogyny and clear violations of basic consent, but I had higher expectations for far more clear cut and well substantiated hateful racism given what was leaked. This article makes it seem more like he's a massive asshole and just somewhat insensitive of language around race. I wonder if the person who leaked this was coming out was trying to soften the blow for Sarver.

I mean, it is easy to pile on in these cases, but some of this doesn't really make a lot of sense.   -- It talks about how Sarver hired Lindsay Hunter and Earl Watson because they were black. There is the issue that they say he was using the n-word, but looking at the hires themselves, the article seems to be implying that hiring black coaches was somehow racist in and of itself. It seems like the writer is trying to have it both ways.   -- Meanwhile, it says Sarver said he hates diversity, but how can we reconcile that with the fact that the Suns employ a Black GM, black coach, and have had several previous black coaches in recent years?  -- There is this whole discussion of Watson and Rich Paul, where somehow Watson concludes he felt a whole "ownership thing" by Sarver, but none of the story -- whoever's version you believe -- seems to suggest there was a racism thing. One side suggested he was insulted by Paul and that's why Watson was told to fire him, and the other that there was a conflict of interest. To be honest, Watson's response to the conflict thing was really weak -- Rich paul wasn't ever his agent? What? He *own's* the whole agency. Anyway, this whole anecdote doesn't really suggest Sarver was particularly bad about anything in my mind. Yeah, maybe a jerk, but that's about it.  -- There is this story about Watson saying Sarver called him F-ing Toxic, but even Watson said *he* called Sarver toxic first. So how is this only on Sarver?  -- The story starts with this anecdote about him quoting the n-word. Okay, but then has the current Suns GM, President, the NBA spkesperson, and the NBAPA president all say they haven't heard any stories like this. How could this guy be a rampant racist and there have been *no* reports to the NBA or player's association from players??  -- There is a story about he shared a picture of his wife in a suns bikini, as if this is some sort of sexism. Really? To be honest, it sounds more sexist to say a picture of a woman in a swimsuit is somehow wrong than the other way around.  Anyway.... I'm not even gonna keep ready this. Maybe he is racist and sexist, but I find this article to be pretty unconvincing. The only person really saying anything is Watson, and that means something, but the guy could be a disgruntled person trying to get back at a guy he feels mistreated him. It wouldn't be the first time.

> In the case of the Oct. 30, 2016, game versus the Warriors, Sarver and his lawyers wrote that Sarver did not have that conversation with Watson but had one with a Suns player who had received a technical foul for what they said was using the N-word during the game. Sarver said he encouraged the player to appeal the technical foul because Green had used the word in the game -- the technical foul was later rescinded by the league.  > Sarver denied Watson's characterization of the incident: "This is absolutely untrue. I remember the game and topic clearly. I of course never used the word myself. During this conversation, I said 'N-word' without saying the full word. The word itself never crossed my lips.  I don't get this. So he denies having that conversation with Watson, but then in the next paragraph says Watson's characterization is incorrect, meaning there *was* a conversation? Unless he's saying a similar conversation took place, but it wasn't with Watson and Watson also misremembered.  > Paul responded to Sarver's remarks by saying that he knew basketball and that they "weren't talking about tennis," Sarver's childhood sport.  This was a dick move by Paul though lol.

> Contract talks eventually led Bledsoe's Klutch Sports agent, Rich Paul, to communicate directly with Sarver -- the Suns owner didn't want to extend Bledsoe's contract in part due to concerns about Bledsoe's durability, plus concerns that the team had performed poorly with him as the starting point guard, according to sources at the time.
